ab.title: Exodus 3
ab.l:
And Moses pastured the flock of Jethro, his father-in-law, the priest
of Midian. And he led the flock behind the wilderness,
and came to the mountain of God, to Horeb.

And
the angel of the Lord appeared to him in the midst of fire
out of the midst of the blackthorn. And he looked, and, lo, the blackthorn
burned with fire, and the blackthorn was not consumed.

And Moses said, ‘Let me now turn aside, and see this
great sight, why the blackthorn is not burnt.’

And the Lord saw that he turned aside to look at, and
God called to him out of the midst of the blackthorn, and said, ‘Moses,
Moses.’ And he said, ‘Lo, am I here.’

And
God said, ‘Do not come near here. Take off your shoes from your feet,
because the place on which you stand is holy ground.’

And He said, ‘I am the God of your father, the God
of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’ And Moses hid
his face, because he was afraid to look on the divine Presence.

And the Lord said, ‘I have surely seen the affliction of my people
who are in Egypt, and have heard their cry in front of
of their oppressors, because I learned their sorrows.

And
my command has come down to rescue them from the hand of the Egypt, and
to bring them up from that land to a better land and widespread land flowing
|with| milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanites, and the Hittites, and the
Amorites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites.

And now, lo, the cry of the children of Israel has come
before me, and also I have seen the oppression with which
the Egyptians oppress them.

And now come,
and I will send you to Pharaoh, and bring out my people,
the children of Israel from Egypt.’

And Moses said
to God, ‘Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh and that
I should bring out the children of Israel from Egypt?’

And
God said, ‘Because my help will be with you, and this
is a sign for you that I am sending you. When you will bring out the people
from Egypt, you will serve God on this mountain.’

And Moses said to God, ‘Lo,
if I come to the children of Israel and say to them, “The God
of your fathers has sent me to you,” and if they say to me, “What is his name?”,
what will I say to them?’

And God said to Moses,
‘I am who I am,’ and He said, ‘Thus shall you say to the children
of Israel, “I Am has sent me to you.”’

And God said moreover
to Moses, ‘Thus you shall say to the children of Israel, “The Lord God
of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God
of Jacob, has sent me to you.” This is my name forever,
and this is my memorial to every single generation.

Go, and
gather the elders of Israel together, and say to them,
“The divine Presence of the Lord God of your fathers appeared to me,
the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, saying, “I have surely remembered
you and what has been done to you in Egypt.

And I have said let me bring you out from the affliction of Egypt
to the land of the Canaanites and the Hittites and the Amorites and the
Perizzites and the Hivites and the Jebusites, to a land flowing
|with| milk and honey.””

And they will listen to your voice, and you shall come, you and
the elders of Israel, to the king of Egypt, and you shall say to him, “The Lord
God of the Hebrews has met with us. And now
let us go a three days’ journey in the wilderness and let us
offer a sacrifice to the Lord our God.”

But I know that
the king of Egypt will not empower you to go,
and not by a mighty hand.

And I will reach out my wrath,
and punish Egypt with all my wonders which
I will do in the midst of it, and after that he will let you go.

And I will put the favour of these people in Egypt’s eyes,
and it shall be that when you go, you will not go empty.

And every woman shall take a loan from her neighbour, and of anyone who lives
in her house: silver vessels, and golden vessels, and clothing.
And you will put them on your sons, and on your daughters,
and you will plunder Egypt.’
